body: Yes, run with `--debug-profile-heap` and Syncthing will create a series of heap profiles as usage grows. Grab the biggest/latest one and post it and we can maybe see what's going on.

Oh, sorry, i missed that one in the `--help`. Here you go:
[heap-337438.pprof.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17939666/heap-337438.pprof.tar.gz)

![profile005](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8a571511-12db-463a-8b74-c8d17da777c2)

The 2GB shown is still far away from the 8GB Syncthing ends up using, where it runs into the `MemoryHigh=8G` limit set by me and gets throttled. 2GB is still more than the memory usage on older versions, so this profile should already show the problem.

(profile taken on Syncthing v1.28.1-rc.2)

Yeah, that's two gigs of cached dir names for the case insensitivity check.

This does seem a bit excessive.

rename.to: Excessive memory usage from cached dir names in v1.28.0

body: Can you post the configs from both sides please? Redacting any IDs and secrets as you like, I'm mostly interested in all the folder and device options as it seems there is a lot going on here.

I have a number of peers and folders, but pausing hosts and folders allowed me to narrow it down.

The causing folder has ~300k files. 200k of those are in one directory, unfortunately. On the local (memleaking) Syncthing node, it shows that a remote node is missing 100k elements. On the web interface of that remote node, only ~10 elements are actually shown as missing. The remote node is running Syncthing v1.27.2. When i downgrade the local node to 1.27, the missing 100k elements are still shown, but the number appears to go down.

Both nodes run on Linux amd64.

[configs.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17940949/configs.tar.gz)

Thanks for investigating!
Yeah, OK, I see where this is coming from, thanks.

Let me modify that, I don't know where this is coming from... In the general sense I can see that our fs caching for case insensitivity lookups is probably mostly ineffective in your setup (too few entries for too short a time), but the thing I thought was broken isn't. (I've written tests to try to prove brokenness, but it's not there.) I don't see why there would be a difference in 1.28 vs earlier releases.

issue.title: Scanning gets stuck during incoming requests since v1.28.0

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

issue.body:
### What happened?

I updated to v1.28.0 on Android, but since this seems to be an issue with the native application I think the report should go here instead of the Android wrapper.

Scanning my Camera folder locks up after a while, even after wiping the entire DB and doing it over. See the attached log for what I get when enabling fs,scanner,walkfs debug logging. I left it like that for half an hour but nothing else appeared except the progress report line repeating again and again, and unrelated messages from connections to other devices.

Switching back to v1.27.12 fixes the issue.

Any suggestions how to debug this further?

### Syncthing version

v1.28.0

### Platform & operating system

Linux arm64

### Browser version

_No response_

### Relevant log output


body: I still don't see how the case caching/registry could do this, but it keeps coming up so I added some debug logging around it. If you can run tomorrows nightly build (otherwise next RC or release), could you repro with `fs` debug logging enabled and provide those logs please - that would then indicate if the registry is working as expected or not.

issue.title: Out-of-memory (OOM) errors:  While processing a directory containing over 100,000 data entries

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: New issues needed to be validated

issue.body:
### What happened?

<!-- Failed to upload "panic-20251011-113415.reported.log" -->
<!-- Failed to upload "panic-20251011-121707.reported.log" -->
<!-- Failed to upload "panic-20251011-121955.log" -->

Issue Description:
While processing a directory containing over 100,000 data entries, we encountered persistent out-of-memory (OOM) errors. This issue occurred consistently across multiple environments, including 32-bit and 64-bit VMs, and various software versions (1.29, 1.30, 2.0.10).

Key Observations:

At the time of failure, the operating system had 7GB of free memory available out of 16GB total.

The application log indicated that the process was using approximately 1.8GB of memory when it failed to allocate a 4MB block.

Interim Solution & Proposed Enhancements:
We have temporarily mitigated the problem by adjusting key configuration parameters. For a more robust long-term solution, we recommend:

Fine-tuning the aforementioned parameters.

Implementing an intelligent memory management mechanism, such as automatic memory degradation or other dynamic allocation strategies, to improve system resilience under heavy load.


### Fix sulution:
file:case fs.go line:20

```
const (
	// How long to consider cached dirnames valid
	caseCacheTimeout   = 10 * time.Second // Increased from 1 second to 10 seconds to reduce cache churn
	caseCacheItemLimit = 64 << 10 // Increased from 4<<10 (4096) to 64<<10 (65536) to reduce memory pressure
)
```

### Syncthing version

2.0.100, 1.29, 1.30, x32 and x64

### Platform & operating system

Windows x64

### Browser version

_No response_

### Relevant log output

```shell
fatal error: out of memory

runtime stack:
runtime.throw({0x7ff7573a3ea8?, 0xc24c550000?})
	runtime/panic.go:1094 +0x4d fp=0x30d0bff638 sp=0x30d0bff608 pc=0x7ff75666fccd
runtime.sysUsedOS(0xc24c548000, 0x14000)
	runtime/mem_windows.go:83 +0x1bb fp=0x30d0bff698 sp=0x30d0bff638 pc=0x7ff75661143b
runtime.sysUsed(...)
	runtime/mem.go:85
runtime.(*mheap).allocSpan(0x7ff757f1d580, 0xa, 0x0, 0x82)
	runtime/mheap.go:1404 +0x487 fp=0x30d0bff740 sp=0x30d0bff698 pc=0x7ff7566249e7
runtime.(*mheap).alloc.func1()
	runtime/mheap.go:1017 +0x5c fp=0x30d0bff788 sp=0x30d0bff740 pc=0x7ff7566241bc
runtime.systemstack(0xc000002a80)
	runtime/asm_amd64.s:513 +0x49 fp=0x30d0bff798 sp=0x30d0bff788 pc=0x7ff756676329
```

issue.title: fix(fs): store `getExpireAdd` mutex in `caseCache` (fixes #9836)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

issue.body:
In #9701 there was a change that put the mutex used for `getExpireAdd` directly in `defaultRealCaser`, which is erroneous because multiple filesystems can share the same `caseCache`.

### Purpose

Fixes #9836 and [Slow sync sending files from Android](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/slow-sync-sending-files-from-android/24208?u=marbens). There may be other issues caused by `getExpireAdd` conflicting with itself, though.

### Testing

Unit tests pass and the case cache and conflict detection _seem_ to behave correctly.

body: If #10430 fixes this issue, and the memory usage is from the `DirNames` calls themselves (which does seem to be the case for the heap profile mentioned in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/9836#issuecomment-2504708749), then the title is not accurate, it's from to-be-cached dir names, not cached dir names.

rename.from: Excessive memory usage from cached dir names in v1.28.0
rename.to: Excessive memory usage from case insensitivity filesystem layer
